column1: Which cytoskeleton is associated with the adherent (adherens) junction?
column8:
Correct: A — Actin filament
Why: Adherens junctions (zonula adherens) are cell–cell anchoring junctions that link actin filaments of adjacent cells via cadherins and catenins.
Exam gold: Adherens = actin, Desmosome = intermediate filaments, Focal adhesion = actin, Hemidesmosome = intermediate filaments.

Correct: A — mixed acini
Why: Serous demilunes (Giannuzzi) are crescent-shaped serous cell caps on mucous acini, typical for mixed (seromucous) glands.
Exam gold: Demilunes = mixed gland (e.g., submandibular/sublingual), parotid = pure serous (no demilunes).

column1: Which of the following cells is NOT localized in connective tissue?
column8:
Correct: A — none is correct
Why: Fibroblasts, macrophages, plasma cells, and eosinophils can all be found in connective tissue.

column1: Which of the following statements regarding conductive cardiomyocytes is NOT correct?
column2: They are smaller than contractile cardiomyocytes
column3: They are bigger than contractile cardiomyocytes
column4: They are stained lighter in HE stain than contractile cardiomyocytes
column5: They have fewer contractile fibrils compared to contractile cardiomyocytes
column6: Their plasmalemma does not form a T-system
column8:
Correct: A — They are smaller than contractile cardiomyocytes
Why: Conductive cardiomyocytes (Purkinje fibers) are larger, paler, and have fewer myofibrils.

column1: What is the shape of the nucleus of a neutrophilic myelocyte?
column8:
Correct (MU-Varna): A — kidney-shaped
Why: MU-Varna teaching accepts kidney-shaped nucleus for neutrophilic myelocyte.
